unnormalised: Okay, so someone asked about the most important documents you need to have as an Indian citizen. It’s a pretty crucial question, tbh. I’ll tell you what my experience has been.
normalised: Okay, so someone asked about the most important documents you need to have as an Indian citizen. It's a pretty crucial question, to be honest. I'll tell you what my experience has been.

unnormalised: First off, you absolutely need an Aadhaar card. My Aadhaar no. is something like 9876-5432-1012 (not real, obviously!). It’s linked to basically everything these days – bank accounts, phone connections, even gas subsidies. You’ll need it for pretty much any government-related work. Remember when I tried to get a new SIM card? They wouldn't budge without Aadhaar verification. It's that important. Plus, the govt keeps pushing linking Aadhaar everywhere.
normalised: First off, you absolutely need an Aadhaar card. My Aadhaar number is something like nine eight seven six dash five four three two dash one zero one two (not real, obviously!). It's linked to basically everything these days – bank accounts, phone connections, even gas subsidies. You'll need it for pretty much any government-related work. Remember when I tried to get a new S-I-M card? They wouldn't budge without Aadhaar verification. It's that important. Plus, the government keeps pushing linking Aadhaar everywhere.

unnormalised: Then there’s the PAN card. My PAN is something like ABCDE1234F. This is essential for any financial transaction, esp. if you're dealing with amounts over Rs. 50,000. Filing income tax? PAN card. Opening a Demat account? PAN card. Receiving a large sum of money? Guess what? PAN card. My uncle, Mr. Sharma, found out the hard way when he couldn’t deposit a check for Rs. 75000 without his PAN.
normalised: Then there's the P-A-N card. My P-A-N is something like A-B-C-D-E one two three four F. This is essential for any financial transaction, especially if you're dealing with amounts over rupee fifty thousand. Filing income tax? P-A-N card. Opening a Demat account? P-A-N card. Receiving a large sum of money? Guess what? P-A-N card. My uncle, Mister Sharma, found out the hard way when he couldn't deposit a check for rupee seventy five thousand without his P-A-N.

unnormalised: Next, the Voter ID. My Voter ID no. is XYZ1234567. This is vital for exercising your democratic right to vote, obviously! It's also accepted as proof of identity and address in many places. I used mine to get a passport a few yrs ago.
normalised: Next, the Voter I-D. My Voter I-D number is X-Y-Z one two three four five six seven. This is vital for exercising your democratic right to vote, obviously! It's also accepted as proof of identity and address in many places. I used mine to get a passport a few years ago.

unnormalised: A passport is also an essential document, especially if you plan to travel abroad. My passport no. is something like P1234567. It’s proof of your citizenship and identity when you’re outside India. Applying for a visa? Passport. Crossing international borders? Passport. Even just booking an international flight requires your passport details.
normalised: A passport is also an essential document, especially if you plan to travel abroad. My passport number is something like P one two three four five six seven. It's proof of your citizenship and identity when you're outside India. Applying for a visa? Passport. Crossing international borders? Passport. Even just booking an international flight requires your passport details.

unnormalised: Then, there's the driving license. My driving license no. is DL123456789012345. Obviously important if you plan on driving! It's proof that you are authorized to operate a vehicle on public roads and good as an id too.
normalised: Then, there's the driving license. My driving license number is D-L one two three four five six seven eight nine zero one two three four five. Obviously important if you plan on driving! It's proof that you are authorized to operate a vehicle on public roads and good as an I-D too.

unnormalised: Lastly, ration card is also very important specially for below poverty line families. My aunt uses it to buy rice for just Rs. 3/kg.
normalised: Lastly, ration card is also very important especially for below poverty line families. My aunt uses it to buy rice for just rupee three per kilogram.

unnormalised: So, yeah, those are the main ones based on my own experience. Keep them safe and updated! Its a real headache to get them re-issued.
